title: Synthetic Recap
body:
ORLANDO – History arrived not with a roar, but with the steady, unstoppable cadence of a player operating on a different plane. In a 100-89 victory for the Orlando Magic over the Vancouver Grizzlies, Shaquille O’Neal authored a performance for the ages, a statistical symphony of pure dominance that left everyone in the arena breathless.

From the opening tip, it was clear Shaq’s force was irresistible. He wasn’t just scoring; he was imposing his will, a whirlwind of power and grace that the Grizzlies had no answer for. He attacked the rim with ferocity, his 46 points coming on a devastatingly efficient 20-of-28 shooting from the field. Every possession was a referendum on Vancouver’s interior defense, and every time, O’Neal delivered the verdict.

But his assault wasn’t confined to the scoreboard. O’Neal was an omnipresent force on the glass, hauling in a monstrous 22 rebounds, 10 of them on the offensive end, snuffing out any hope of a Vancouver stop. He was a one-man wrecking crew, and when he wasn’t scoring, he was orchestrating, dishing out 5 assists as the defensive collapse around him opened up his teammates.

The Magic needed every bit of his Herculean effort. Despite the final margin, the Grizzlies, led by Blue Edwards’ 20 points, stayed within striking distance for much of the contest. But on this night, there was no counter for greatness. Shaq’s final line—46 points, 22 rebounds, 5 assists—wasn’t just a box score; it was a monument to a single player’s ability to completely overwhelm a game. The final score tells you who won, but the story of this night belongs solely to Shaquille O’Neal, a giant who reached historic heights.
